clinical_study.official_title: Motion Analysis of Delirium in Intensive Care Units (ICUs)

brief_summary.textblock: Delirium, as a common complication of hospitalization, poses significant health problems in hospitalized patients. Though about a third of delirium cases can benefit from intervention, detecting and predicting delirium is still very limited in practice. A common characterization of delirium is changes in activity level, causing patients to become hyperactive or hypoactive which is manifested in facial expressions and total body movements. This pilot study is designed to test the feasibility of a delirium detection system using movement data obtained from 3-axis wearable accelerometers and commercially available camera and facial recognition video system, in conjunction with electronics medical record (EMR) data, to analyze the relation of whole-body movement as well as facial expressions with delirium.

detailed_description.textblock: The aim of the study is to assess the potential of motion and facial expression data for detecting delirium in ICU patients by comparing motion and facial expression patterns in delirium and control group. In this study, the investigators will use ActiGraph accelerometer to record each subject's movement patterns. Also, a processed video using a commercially available camera interfaces with specialized program to identify patient facial expressions and movement patterns. A total of 40 participants will be enrolled with delirium and 20 patients without delirium will be used as control group. Motion profiles will be compared in the motorically defined subgroups (hyperactive, hypoactive, normal) based on accelerometer and facial recognition data. Then differences in facial expression, number of changes in postures and percentage of time spent moving between motorically defined subgroups and in delirium and control group. EMR data will also be used to assess the feasibility of detecting delirium by additionally including information on related risk factors.

primary_outcome.time_frame: Changes from Baseline up to 7 Days
primary_outcome.description: Confusion Assessment Method for detection of delirium

primary_outcome.measure: Memorial Delirium Assessment Scale (MDAS) will be used for changes from baseline up to 7 days between the groups.
primary_outcome.time_frame: Changes from Baseline up to 7 Days
primary_outcome.description: MDAS denotes motor profile and defines motor subtyping. It has 10 items which assesses several areas of cognitive functioning (memory, attention, orientation and disturbances in thinking) and psychomotor activity. The items are rated on a four point scale (0-3) based on the current interaction with the patient or by assessment of behavior. A score of 13 shows the diagnosis of delirium.

primary_outcome.measure: Delirium Motor Subtyping Scale (DMSS-4) will be used for changes from baseline up to 7 days between the groups.
primary_outcome.time_frame: Changes from Baseline up to 7 Days
primary_outcome.description: Scoring from DMSS-4 which has 5 hyperactive and 8 hypoactive symptoms requires at least two symptoms to be present from either the hyperactive or hypoactive list to meet subtype criteria. The higher the score the higher the delirium.

primary_outcome.time_frame: Changes from Baseline up to 7 Days
primary_outcome.description: To determine sleep quality of patient for given day.

secondary_outcome.description: Death at any time during admission

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of subjects on mechanical ventilation
secondary_outcome.description: Number of subjects requiring mechanical ventilation greater than 48 hours.

other_outcome.measure: Facial amimia versus non-amimic expressions between the groups
other_outcome.time_frame: Changes from Baseline up to 7 Days
other_outcome.description: Frequency of presence of facial amimia versus non-amimic expressions between the groups.

other_outcome.time_frame: Changes from Baseline up to 7 Days
other_outcome.description: Percentage of time spent moving versus static position

arm_group.description: ICU patients with a positive Confusion Assessment Method (CAM) score; observational using accelerometers, commercially available camera, and Internet Pod (iPod).
ICU patients with a negative Confusion Assessment Method (CAM) score; observational using accelerometers, commercially available camera, and Internet Pod (iPod).
Healthy subjects that sleep in their home environment; observational using accelerometers, cortisol swabs, and Internet Pod (iPod)

intervention.description: 3 accelerometers (placed on upper arm, wrist and ankle) and 1 placed on wall as ambient light sensor
As part of facial recognition video system
Monitors noise levels in the room
Cortisol level collected through self administered salivary swab

study_pop.textblock:
ICU Patients: Patients who been hospitalized in an intensive care unit and have risk factors to develop delirium or delirium has been suspected by their medical provider.
Healthy Controls: People who are healthy and sleep in their home environment.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria (ICU Patients):
- Intensive care unit patient
- 18 years of age or older
Exclusion Criteria (ICU Patients):
- Anticipated intensive care unit stay less than one day
- Less than 18 years of age
- Inability to wear a motion sensor watch (ActiGraph)
Inclusion Criteria (Healthy Controls):
- 18 years of age or older.
- sleeps in home environment
Exclusion Criteria (Healthy Controls):
- does not sleep in home environment
- Less than 18 years of age
- Inability to wear a motion sensor watch (ActiGraph)
